content: It's not as easy as it sounds. I'm tackling this for my app using a RAG based semantic search + direct memory lookup tool and memory extraction after chat sessions end.
author: ticktockbent#0

content: Part of the problem is context aware memory. Claude can choke down 200k tokens in a prompt but beyond like 50k it starts to lose the thread. Every bit of memory you inject eats into that context so you start losing ground. You have to make sure the memory you inject is relevant to what's being discussed

content: It's a bit more complicated than that. After memory extraction you have to build semantic connections and map them out into vector space. Claude needs to know what a memory means and what it's associated with so it knows what to pull up next time.
author: ticktockbent#0

content: its all just a big function that spits out a vector. Thats what modern AI is
author: pakeke#0

content: If you just rely on text search you get weird interactions like "mother in law" won't map to "family" because that's not the same text but with semantic connections they will
author: ticktockbent#0

content: Well sherlock holmes said that he has a set amount of storage space in his brain too, and that's why he discards irrelevant stuff and complies things that aren't so relevant but still need to be stored, and then only keeps the things at the front of his mind that are useful for what he needs

author: ticktockbent#0

content: What's a context window? Like the chat? is that a context window?
author: aurora_smith_#0

content: like it's so unintuitive that something so simple can display such emergently intelligent properties
author: pakeke#0

content: what a time to be alive honestly
author: pakeke#0

content: An LLM can only process a certain number of tokens in a single call, that's the context window. For claude it's about 200k tokens. That's why long chats have to end or be compacted, because they ran over the context limit
author: ticktockbent#0

content: OH. Because I've heard that every time you send a new prompt, it literally just appends that to the rest of the convo, and resends the ENTIRE convo. Okay. So you're saying that that entire process, can only use a set number of tokens or compute points. okay
author: aurora_smith_#0

content: Yep that's how it works. The whole chat is fed back in every time with notations on who said what. Think of it like the LLM's attention span. Once the chat is bigger than that, it can't really follow the conversation. Even at maximum it gets a little iffy about paying attention.
author: ticktockbent#0

content: So how would we fix that.... well he doesn't need to resend the entire process. It could compile the chat into notes about the chat... AH. I see. But then you lose some details which is why the AIs are awesome about highlevel abstract philosophy and crap when it comes to details. They can remember everything I tell them about metaphysics but somehow forget my name.
author: aurora_smith_#0

content:
But the most important thing to realize; is that the ONLY input an LLM takes is the context window.

It literally takes a stream of tokens, and spits out the next token.
Then it forgets everything, re-reads everything, (including the new token that was just added), and then spits out the NEXT token.

Isn't that incredible?

Imagine if you were having a conversation, and every time you said a word, you forgot what you were saying lol. That's pretty much the experience of LLMs, yet they still form cohesive sentences.
author: pakeke#0

content: Well different companies fix it in different ways. Some compact the chat and feed in a shorter summary but you lose nuance. Some just discard older messages but you lose information. Some make the context window bigger but then you add cost. Gemini can take 1 million tokens in context but might take longer to process.

content:
eg,
if model is writing a function, and it comes across a part that'll be complicated, it can write some "planning" comments for a while, like

/* [THINKING]
...
...
*/
and then continue code.
Postprocess script clears the CoT comment block
author: pakeke#0

content: Oh another thing I do which seems to work alright is I use a hierarchy in my claude.md - The claude.md is just a map to the codebase and I put agent files in other folders. The initial file just points to those files "If you're working on the frontend, look at /web/agents.md" etc and those have specifics for the code there. It helps it remain focused in a large code base
